titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Samuel Miller Brownell Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Carol King

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday April 24, 2019 at 07:13

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of correspondence, funding proposals, project reports, subject files, writings, research material, and printed materials that document the career of Samuel Miller Brownell as an educator and consultant in the field of urban educational administration during his tenure at Yale University and the University of Connecticut. Brownell's contributions to the creation and administration of the Mid-Career Program in City School Administration at the Center for the Study of Education at Yale University comprise the main focus of the collection.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Samuel Miller Brownell Papers (MS 1491). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in three series: I. Yale Files, 1923-1982. II. Mid-Career Program in City School Administration Files, 1950-1986. III. University of Connecticut Files, 1966-1970.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Samuel Miller Brownell was born in Peru, Nebraska, on April 3, 1900. He received a B.A. degree from the University of Nebraska in 1921, an M.A. from Yale in 1924, and a Ph.D. from Yale in 1926. Brownell was superintendent of schools in Grosse Pointe, Michigan, from 1927 to 1938. From 1938 to 1953, he was a professor of educational administration at Yale. He served as president of New Haven Teachers College from 1947 to 1953. Brownell served as the United States commissioner of education from 1953 to 1956 and was superintendent of schools in Detroit from 1956 to 1966. He returned to Yale University in 1966, accepting a joint position with the University of Connecticut as a professor, advisor, and consultant in the field of urban educational administration. Although his assignment at the University of Connecticut was completed in 1970, he continued his role at Yale University until 1973. Brownell died in 1990.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of correspondence, funding proposals, project reports, subject files, writings, research material, and printed materials that document the career of Samuel Miller Brownell as an educator and consultant in the field of urban educational administration during his tenure at Yale University and the University of Connecticut. Brownell's contributions to the creation and administration of the Mid-Career Program in City School Administration at the Center for the Study of Education at Yale University comprise the main focus of the collection.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

controlaccess.corpname: Yale University. Center for the Study of Education. Mid-Career Program in City School Administration

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Yale Files document the primary initiatives of the education department of Yale University with which Samuel Brownell was involved, mainly from the mid 1960s to the mid 1970s. The General files, arranged chronologically, deal primarily with the administration of the department during Brownell's early years at Yale and there is great overlap of subject matter among folders. Topics include staffing issues; registration procedures; statistics and projections; budget items; curriculum content; publicity; reports; proposals; and related items. The succeeding subject files focus on the various education courses available on the undergraduate and graduate level for advanced teaching degrees, as well as outreach programs within the community for high school students. These files are arranged alphabetically by topic or title and chronologically within a topic. The folders contain materials created and acquired by Samuel Brownell as a member of a committee or board. Not only is Brownell's contribution to the teaching administration program at Yale documented, but also a history of the department of education at Yale University during his tenure.

Mid-Career Program in City School Administration Files (MCP), 1950-1986

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Mid-Career Program Files document the contribution of Samuel Brownell in the creation and administration of the Mid-Career Program in City School Administration, the first operation of Yale's Center for Education Studies. Established in 1970, the non-degree program offered fellowships to approximately ten city school administrators, particularly minority members, annually for an academic year or a semester in residence. The program aimed to further the education and experience of city school superintendents, assistant superintendents, and directors of state and federal educational departments. Supported by the W. K. Kellogg Foundation and Yale University, the program was intended as a permanent one but was terminated in 1974 due to a lack of additional funding sources. The files consist of correspondence by and about the Fellows and resource persons involved in the program and are arranged alphabetically by personal or organizational name. The subject files contain drafts of funding proposals and trace fundraising venues. The series concludes with documentation of the Mid-Career Program arranged chronologically by academic semester, and alphabetically by subject within a semester. Materials referencing MCP are also interspersed in the subject files of Series I.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains files compiled by Brownell during his time spent at the University of Connecticut, part of his joint appointment with Yale University, as a visiting lecturer and resource person in the area of advanced school administration in urban areas. The files are arranged alphabetically by topic and contain correspondence, memoranda, reports, and printed matter.
